9.30.17  12:08 pm   I know this is probably a tough question, but do you have any tips on writing melodies? If you give me a melody, I can arrange it (figure out harmonies, bass line, drum beats etc)... but I always hear people say that melodies just 'come to them', like they just appear out of nowhere in their heads like magic... but this has never been the case for me. I usually write a chord pattern that I think sounds interesting, then I try to build a melody from the notes in the chords. Sometimes I can do it, sometimes I can't. But I know I'm doing it backwards. Melody should come first. Melody is the most important part of a song.

     when writing a melody, it's sometimes hard to know 'why' you're writing the melody if there's no lyric with it. like, who cares if the notes go here or there? what's it for? what is this even about? but when you are delivering a message, through words (musical words) then all of a sudden everything has meaning. i'm not suggesting you do lyrics first, that route seems bland as hell to me. i'm suggesting you do lyric and melody at the same time. perhaps other people do it differently but that's the only way it goes for me

9.30.17  11:56 am   9.29.17  9:32 pm I checked with the committee. They told me that they register songs once they are accepted as music. But they're not the ones to determine rather or not something is accepted as music. They told me to refer to you in order to get my Certificate of Acceptance... which I will then have to bring back to them, in order to officially register something as music. 

     nothing is music

But you wouldnt expirence that instsant anyway

Weird huh?

9.30.17  6:41 am   What are you trying to say in your music?

9.30.17  5:48 am   it appears you have moved awy from 10 second long shorts. all your videos since history of the entire world, i guess has been longer than 1 minute and two of them have been music videos. are you moving away from shorts and pushing closer towards music videos? also what is steves real name?

     just when i was ready to move onto videos a bit longer, i got really popular on vine. vine was a platform that only allowed videos of up to 6 seconds. this was great news because i had a great audience who never expected anything longer, but bad because i was just getting ready to make them longer but i actually had to make even more of them that were shorter. so by the end of 2015 i was ready to explode and when i finally finished history of japan, it did very well on youtube, and quickly gave me an even larger audience there than on vine. so needless to say at that point i was more than exhausted with the -10 sec format, and also the non-vine audience was very confused about those videos in the first place, because they didn't realize that they were being composed with the vine platform in mind

9.30.17  4:30 am   will you start making short videos again? If no, why?

9.30.17  4:12 am   Many notable figures throughout history have been successful publicly and deeply flawed personally. Is your opinion of an artist's work affected by your feelings regarding them as a person,

     hopefully not

     or are you able to appreciate the art as separate from the artist? 

     it's important to remember that usually i don't actually know the artist personally. sometimes very famous people might have a flawed public image, which doesn't necessarily reflect how they really are. which is why it's even more important to look at the art directly, and ignore whatever scandals the newspapers may be trying to focus on

     oh thank goodness i don't have to do that. otherwise i would never be doing this in the first place
